text: The perfect portrait of New England in springtime bloom, awash in a soft mid-morning light. All is deathly quiet.

Every streetlight extinguished. Not a car on the road. Not a soul to be seen. Rows of shops closed for business. Their storefront windo eerily pristine, adorned with classic Americana kitsch. Two empty rocking chairs tremble in the breeze. A flock of sparrows coasts overhead, beyond the web of tangled branches. A v-formation of little black and brown specks soaring the skies, returning home for the season. PRE-LAP: Tick. Tick. Tick.

A wall clock, keeping time. It’s cozy in here, but not warm. A palpable chill hangs o the lived-in parlor. Nobody’s been by in some time. Four beaming, airbrushed faces in a framed photograph on mantelpiece. Father, mother, two-point-five kids. The glass on the frame is just barely frosted over. ANGLE on the FRONT DOOR. From outside: A pair of muted FOOTSTEPS. The adjacent window QUIVERS as a small SCREWDRIVER slides underneath the sill. It’s a tight fit. The screwdriver’s shaft SCISSORS back a forth, slowly forcing its way through. GRINDING the sill’ hardwood base into FLAKES, misting through the air like s A GLOVED HAND reaches into the newly formed crevice, angl its way toward the front door. TWISTING the LOCK...  The door swings open, revealing a MAN, early 30s, on the porch. He wears a fleece jacket, baggy workman jeans and hiking boots. Thick-framed glasses. Average build. This is DEL. He scuffs his boots on the floor mat. Surveys the room. His eyes land on the ticking wall clock. He plucks the cl from its moorings. Removes the batteries. The ticking sound abruptly dies. He re-hangs the clock. Straightens it. He deposits the batteries in a zip-lock bag. Folds the ba into the front pocket of a worn Kipling backpack. Swings backpack over his shoulder. The ape keychain dangles at Del’s side, open-mouthed in a state of perpetual awe.

Del rummages clinically through the empty home. He strips the batteries from the smoke alarm. From Daddy' electric toothbrush. From the kids’ toy RCs and night lig and mobile gaming consoles. From Mommy’s vibrator. He neglects the wad of cash on the dresser. The jewelry. flat-screen television. He scans the bookshelf, index finger outstretched. Plucks the more obscure titles. He removes the family portrait from its frame. Sets the f upright just where he found it.

Del kneels in the grass, a surgical mask over his nose an mouth. He’s spray-painting a large white X across the law He gets to his feet. Brushes the dirt from his knees. Str off his gloves, revealing two pale, bony hands. We pull back to see every single house on the block, all way to the end of the street, marked with the exact same

Del coasts the aisles with a shopping cart. Most of the grocery’s stock is still in place, though the fluorescent lights, fridges and freezers are down. He checks expiration dates. Takes only what he needs.
Del’s truck pulls to a stop outside the town library.

Del replenishes the AAA batteries in his Brother P-Touch® Label Maker. He traverses the stacks, adding the books from his haul t the library’s inventory. Labeling them with their proper Dewey Decimal codes.

A wide assortment of plants, shrubs and vegetation. Del circulates, spritzing each of them with water. He listens closely. The roots purr and gurgle under their soil, lapping up the new liquid. He savors the sound.
Del pilots a heavy-duty street sweeper up and down the ro its twin brushes WHIRRING and GRINDING.
Del sits on the floor, piecing together a complicated jig puzzle of a nautical tableau. We pull back to discover the room is carpeted with a seemingly endless collection of puzzles, all completed.

The sun’s last light casts intense and powerful streaks across the sky. A lone sailboat bobs on the ocean’s surfa Del’s bare feet hang from the boat’s edge as he reads one his books. His nose swathed in layers of sunblock. His fishing rod STIRS. Del JUMPS. He abandons his book, grabbing hold of the rod and reelin his line, mad with excitement.

A toy aquarium, battery-operated, filled with plastic clownfish and glowing neon blue water. Del’s curled up on a hammock in the darkness, munching on well-balanced meal of cooked fish, brown rice and veggies He watches an old screwball comedy on a laptop. Chuckles through mouthfuls of food. He keeps an eye on the laptop’s battery power. It’s dwind at nineteen percent. A mammoth pile of unused laptops and portable DVD players rests beside his hammock, stacked like pancakes.
Del spreads out on a blanket, gazing up at the nighttime Every single star is visible, every constellation defined awesome natural panorama that belongs to Del and Del alon He falls asleep smiling.
Del shaves in the mirror. Clips his fingernails. Tweezes eyebrows. Swabs the wax from his ears. He pops two gummy vitamins.

Del jogs past rows and rows of suburban houses marked wit his white xX. He crosses into a new part of town, where the front lawns still bare. Unexplored territory. Del stops to catch his breath. He scans the area. Listens Hears movement. He turns, alarmed. It’s the window blinds from a nearby house. They’re rustl scratching softly against the glass... Somebody’s inside. Del approaches the porch, moving furtively. He presses his ear to the door. From the other side -- something’s CLAWING against the do paneling. Something low to the ground. Del thinks. He turns the knob. The door’s unlocked. He pushes it open A small DOG bursts forth, wild with newfound freedom. Paw frantically at Del’s leg. Eyes wide and watery. It’s a pug, and a fat one at that. Filthy. Rabid with ene And its sharp talons, long ungroomed and ill-maintained, DEEP into Del’s SKIN... Del shakes the thing off his leg. Nudges it outside with leg. Shuts the door behind him.

Del instantly GAGS. This place REEKS. It’s PUTRID.  Flies circling in droves. Dog shit everywhere. Del whips the surgical mask over his nose and mouth. He breathes heavily, his eyes pooling from the stench. He makes his way through the house. Steps over a big, bul bag of DOG KIBBLE -- year’s supply -- it’s been CLAWED IN He proceeds cautiously into the kitchen. The flies’ buzzi amplifies, grows DEAFENING... There it is. Slumped across the tiled floor, contorted in awkward, awful position... a BODY. A woman. Very old. Very dead. Del processes the gruesome scene. He continues into the living room. There’s a second body, slouched over in a leather armchai Head facing away from Del and toward the defunct televisi A halo of flies overhead, almost angelic. The husband. Also very old. Also very dead. The TV remote still locked in his hand. Del pulls away the surgical mask. Squats down to meet the rotting corpse face-to-face. The man’s eyes are marbled over, glazed white. Del shimmies the remote from the man’s ice-cold hand. Pop out the batteries. Pockets them.

Del hops over the woman’s body to the trash drawer. Extra the garbage bags all at once. He sweeps up the mess. Scrubs the floor. Collects the dog droppings and scattered pet food into the bags. He yanks the rug out from under the furniture. Tears out shower curtain. Wraps the bodies into them, burrito-style He pulls the couple’s yellowed wedding portrait from its frame. They look youthful, happy. He replaces the empty frame on the bureau.

Del takes out the trash. He pauses at the sight of the fat pug dog, sitting eagerl the curb. Staring back at him. Tail wagging. INT. DEL’S TRUCK - DAY Del loads the bodies into the back of his truck. The dog’s seated in the passenger seat, gazing out somber at the newly sprayed white X on its owners’ lawn.
Del off-loads the bodies into the dirt.

Del digs a hole with a well-worn shovel. The dog watches at his side, panting. INT. DEL’S TRUCK - DAY Del returns to his truck. He looks in the side mirror. The dog’s pacing the woods in circles, sniffing around at patch of fresh grave. Del starts his car. The dog looks up. Del turns away. Starts driving. The dog barks, strained. Chases after the truck with effo its stubby legs giving out easily. Del accelerates, staring forward. The dog’s barking grows distant in his wake. He flinches. Takes his foot off the gas. Allows the dog t catch up to him.

Del dumps a bucket of water over the dog.  He grooms the dog’s nails with a small pair of scissors. He peeks under the dog’s hood. It’s male. He prints out a label. Affixes it to the dog’s new collar. “NAME: DEWEY.”
Del walks Dewey on a leash. Dewey circles a fire hydrant with mild interest.
Del and Dewey play fetch. Dewey moves very slowly.

Del eats a home-cooked meal at a cluster of desks, readin library book on pet care. Dewey lingers at his feet. Del feeds him a baby carrot. INT. CHILDREN’S SECTION - LIBRARY - NIGHT Del installs Dewey in an enclosed pen outfitted with bean cushions and a bowl of water. Dewey roams the perimeter, restless. Del exits.

Del picks from an assortment of colorful chew toys. Tests their squeaking capabilities. INT. CHILDREN’S SECTION - LIBRARY - DAY Del returns to Dewey’s pen with a shopping bag filled wit toys and treats. He stops. The bean bags are TORN APART. Beans EVERYWHERE. Water bowl OVERTURNED. The pen’s BREACHED... Dewey’s GONE Del rounds a corner. A shred of paper catches on his shoe inspects it -- it’s a page from a picture book. Ripped apart. Destroyed.  He looks ahead. Sees the remnants of an entire stock of children’s books, all RIPPED to SHREDS. Del panics. He sinks to his hands and knees. Tries to gat the scraps and re-order them. It’s a hollow task. They’re all ruined. Del starts to tear up. He turns. Dewey’s gazing at him. Munching on one of the pages. Unrepentant. Del takes a deep breath. INT. DEL’S TRUCK - DAY Del drives, steadfast. In the passenger seat: An overflowing trash bag filled wi every last one of the pet supplies. He peers in the rearview. Dewey stares back at him, curio
Del parks his car for the evening. He’s alone now. INT. CHILDREN’S SECTION - LIBRARY - NIGHT Del surveys the empty space where Dewey’s pen once was. He smooths out the creases in the carpet.
Del re-files the books on pet care.
Del watches another old screwball comedy. He doesn’t laugh. Shuts the laptop.  10.
It’s a windy day at sea. Del’s sailboat rocks with the wa swaying up and down. Del shrouds himself in a blanket.
Del eats dinner in silence.

Del stares at the plastic fish in his toy aquarium, swimm back and forth, smiles etched on their faces. He turns on his side in the hammock. Tries to sleep. Just then: A low RASP. Barely audible. Del perks up. He scrambles to his TRANSISTOR RADIO. Tunes to the correct frequency. The sound sharpens. It’s a VOICE.
Hello? Del’s eyes widen.
Can anyone hear me? Del watches the radio in awe.
Please. Please, somebody be there. Del grabs the radio. Holds down the talk button. Opens hi mouth to speak... He falters.
(weak) No. Del takes his finger off the button.
No. He SMASHES the RADIO.  11.
No. He chokes. Hyperventilates. Inhales sharply.
Oh god. Oh god. Suddenly: BANG. BANG. BANG. From outside. Sounds like a HAIL of GUNFIRE. Del BOLTS.

Del rushes out onto the roof, just in time to catch the mighty FIREWORKS DISPLAY on the HORIZON. The night sky is RIDDLED with TECHNICOLOR. The stars flus away, overwhelmed by the dramatic BARRAGE of LIGHT and SO Rockets soaring upward and rippling through the atmospher exploding violently, shredding the heavens... It’s BLINDI Del shields his face. Covers his ears. Screams. His voice is DROWNED OUT.

Del barricades the door. Blacks out the window with thick strips of duct tape, immersing himself in TOTAL DARKNESS. We can still hear the fireworks in full force outside. Del locks himself in a stall, curling his knees up into h chest. He gropes a SWITCHBLADE in his hand. His grip is shaky, unstable. The knife drops to the floor landing with a small CLINK. Del shuts his eyes. Takes a series of deep breaths.
(in SOTTO) Please. Please no.  12.
The radio, smashed into pieces, crackles quietly.
(distorted) Can you hear me now? The receiver light fizzles out.
Del wakes up. It’s quiet outside. He takes a peek through the window. The skies are clear.
Del sidles out from the library’s double doors. There’s no one in sight. He listens closely. Hears a sound, very distant. It’s a CAR ALARM.

A terrible wreck. There’s a STATION WAGON up on the curb, FLATTENED under a felled LAMPPOST. Windshield SMASHED IN. Engine FUMING. The alarm BLARES. Del approaches cautiously, knife outstretched. The driver's incapacitated. Maybe dead. Del squints for a better look. The driver is female. Almo certainly the woman from the radio. He edges closer. She’s young. Late teens or so. Gash on h forehead. Looks nasty. Probably dead. Del opens the car door.  13. The body slumps out into Del’s arms. He checks for a pulse... Her eyes flicker open. They stare at one another.
You're here. She smiles.

I’m gonna fuck you into the next dimension. She laughs. Slips back into unconsciousness. Del sets her down in the grass, taking care not to bang h head. Returns to the car. The dash is papered with deflated potato chip bags and em liquor bottles and stray undergarments. He looks in the backseat, spots her transistor radio. Her leftover fireworks. A Polaroid camera. A GameBoy. Two bul floral-print suitcases, frayed at the seams. He pops the glove compartment. Finds a small HANDGUN, bur among loose papers. He peers over his shoulder at the young woman splayed out the grass. Contemplates his next move.

Del unzips the suitcases. Sifts through the wrinkled clot and toiletries. He uncovers a weathered PHOTO of a FAMILY. Taped together places -- it looks as if it’s been torn up before. The girl. Her mother, father, little sister. All smiles. Underneath, he finds a newer series of overexposed Polaro selfies taken at various iconic national landmarks. In ea of them, the girl mugs for the camera with a ridiculous f He lingers on a photo taken at the crest of the Grand Can She's sticking her tongue out at him. This is GRACE.  14.

Grace stirs awake. Her vision stabilizes. She's in a BEDROOM, sparsely decorated. The windows are BOARDED SHUT from the outside. A sliver of DAYLIGHT pours from a neglected crack. She sits up with pain. Runs her hand through her hair. He forehead’s dressed in layers of GAUZE. It STINGS. She gets to her feet. Feels DIZZY. Grabs a trash can, dig her head in. HURLS.
Ugh. Fuck me. She wipes her mouth. Heads to the door. Reaches for the k It’s LOCKED. She RAPS her FISTS on the DOOR.

Hello? Hello--? Nothing. She flings open the dresser drawers. They’re all EMPTY. The room’s been cleaned out completely. The only spare it bottle of hand sanitizer on the night stand. She hears a pair of FOOTSTEPS. Turns back to the door. Se shadow pass across the small round PEEPHOLE.
Is there anyone else?
What’s going on?
Answer my question, please.
What’s your question?
Is there anyone else?
It’s just me in here.
I know that already.  15.
Oh, so it’s my fault your question was fucking stupid. The shadow disappears from the peephole.
Wait!
Is there anybody else?
There’s no one else.
Anywhere? Grace’s eyes narrow in on the door.
Are you not--
Anywhere? There’s a hint of panic in his voice. Grace processes. She exhales slowly.
Anywhere.
It's just you?
Just me and you.
That’s all?
Yeah. That’s it. We’re it. A long pause on the other end.
Why are you still alive?  16.
Del stands on the other end of the door, watching Grace through the peephole’s fishbowl POV. Grace looks directly at him.
Why are you?
Grace waits. Finally, Del speaks up.
What about the gun?
Gun? Which gun?
The gun in your glove compartment.
Oh, that gun. I found it on the road a few months back. I figured maybe it’d come in handy one day.
Against who?
Well... who’s to say they don’t all come back from the dead and try to eat our brains?
That won’t happen.
Why not?
Because it doesn’t happen.
And the entire human population of earth dropping dead in a single instant on a Tuesday afternoon, does that not happen either? No response.  17.
Will you let me out?
I can’t yet.
Come on, man. (a pause) I‘1l make it worth your while. She lets the last word linger.

I’m going to unlock the door. That'll cue you to start counting to fifteen Mississippi. I’1l be counting too, from farther away. After fifteen Mississippi you can open the door. I won’t be here. Don’t look for me.
Hold on.
There's a car outside, it’s got a full tank of gas and all your belongings, minus the gun. You shouldn’t have that.
Dude, what the fuck--?
You have to leave. You have to leave and forget you were ever here and never come back. Please.
But... we’re all that’s left.
I’m going to start counting now.
Are you listening to me? I said we're the only ones still out here! We’re the sole fuckin’ survivors, man! You can’t just ghost me like we're in fucking middle school--!
One Mississippi.  18. The doorknob CLICKS.
I'm leaving now, two Missi-- Grace opens the door. Meets Del head-on. Smirks.
You're tall.
What are you doing?
You sounded shorter.
Please go back inside and close the door, this isn’t right. It’s not what we talked about.
You're bossy too. We can work around that.
There’s nothing to work around. You're leaving.
You think it’s a coincidence we found each other?
No. You were drinking and you crashed your car on my street.
Ah, that’s right.
It’s not funny. In your drunken binge you took down a lamppost, and now I have to fix it. That’s going to require substantial renovations and-- and considerable labor--
Labor.
Yes. Manpower.  19.
Man-power.
Stop that.
C’mon. You know as well as I do why He kept the two of us alive.
Who? Who kept us alive? Grace points upward.
Wow. Okay.
Haven’t you ever heard of “be fruitful and--
--and multiply,” yes. It’s from the King James Bible, Genesis 1:28, call two twenty fifty-two.
What’s that?
It was an English translation commissioned by King James I in the early sixteenth century-- or maybe the seventeenth--
Not the Bible, the number.
Genesis 1:28 is where the passage appears in the text.
The second one. The two-twenty whatever you said...
Two twenty fifty-two. It’s the call number for that edition.
Call number?  20.
Every book has one.
They do? Are you sure?
Yes, I’m very sure. I don’t really have time to talk to you anymore--
Are you retarded or something? Del SNAPS.
Fuck off. Okay? Just... please leave me alone. I have a lot of work to do today. I’m already behind schedule, even without factoring in the lamppost.
I can’t believe this.
The engine’s running in your car. You're wasting gas.
Right. And that’s bad for the environment. He gives her a look. She laughs.
You're making fun of me.
No.
I've gotta go. He turns to leave. Grace’s smile fades.
No. Come on. Del starts down the stairs.  21.
You're making me feel like I'ma fucking asshole or-- hey, listen, I’m sorry-- will you wait a minute? Del quickens his pace. Grace follows him outside.
Grace steps out into the light. She looks around in awe. Del hands She turns
Oh my god. her the car keys. She barely notices.
This is where you live? You really live here all alone?
Yes.
Where are the bodies?
Which ones?
Which ones? All of them. Everyone died where they stood, all at once. No warnings, no symptoms, just-- to Del.

You can barely drive a mile without getting one of them caught in your tires. Everywhere you look it’s just piles and piles of bodies. And the smell, that god-awful smell that’s everywhere... She inhales the cool air.
It’s not here.
Nope.
What happened?
I buried them.
All of them? Alone? That’s impossible.

No, it’s just tedious. I started with the public spaces. The outdoor areas. Then I moved on to the shops and restaurants and offices. As of late I’ve been clearing out the residences. The town’s population was 9,539. I’m at 8,840. That’s a 92% clearance rate thus far. It’s actually 92.6, but I round down.
Why?
Rounding up would be giving myself more credit than I deserve.
No. I mean, why did you bury all the bodies?
(matter-of-fact) They smelled. They were ugly. So I got rid of them. Grace thinks.
I want to stay.
That's not possible.
Don’t you ever get lonely? Del cracks a smirk.
No. I don’t get lonely.  23.
You're... you’re telling me you’re totally fine allowing the human race to go extinct?
It’s out of my hands.
Did you fall asleep during sex ed? I’m game, man. DTF. You don’t even have to buy me dinner first. She extends her arms outward.
Take me, you bastard.
Okay. How old are you?
Nineteen. I think. It’s been hard to keep track.
Great. So the average age of menopause is fifty-one. That gives us roughly thirty-two years in which we can propagate.
I love it when you talk dirty.
Oh, I’m just getting started. Now best case scenario, my sperm’s hyper-virile, we max out our capacity and have you on rotation twelve months out of the year. Grace winces.
You want to put me on rotation? Like a cow?
Don’t look at me. I’m just fleshing out your repopulation theory to its logical extreme.
Right. Sure.
Now, assuming none are multiple births, no twins or triplets in the mix, that’s forty-two children maximum. Right? I think that’s right. We can get a calculator.
Oh no, I trust your data.

Great. So that’s forty-two of our children that are then obligated to breed with their siblings to further procreate. And due to the heightened risk of developmental disabilities in inbred children, our descendants would have a severely diminished capacity for survival and would likely die out within a matter of one or two generations, max.
You don’t know that.
Of course I do.
It worked before. Del shakes his head.
I don’t believe in myth. It’s good literature, that’s all.
How can you be so cynical?
I'm a pragmatist. I recommend it highly. Good-bye now-- I’m sorry, what did you say your name was?
Grace. Grace Wilkins.
Good-bye, Grace Wilkins. Best of luck out there. Del strolls off.  25.
Del fills his buckets with water. Grace appears beside hi
I can help clear the bodies.
I don’t need help. I’m 92% done.
You'll get done a lot quicker with an extra pair of hands. And we can start planning our expansion.
Expansion?
To the next town. And the next one after that. I bet we can clear the whole county in no time.
I’m not interested in clearing the county or any of the other towns. He gets to his feet.
My obligation starts and ends with this town. It’s my home. It’s been my home as long as I’ve lived. The least I can do is keep it clean.
But there’s so much else out there.
That's a subjective opinion.
When was the last time you left?
I’m not sure how that’s important.
That long, huh? Del doesn’t respond. He hauls the buckets to his truck. G grabs two herself.  26.
I’m staying here whether you like it or not.
Why? I’ve been nothing but rude to you all morning.
I’m an extrovert. I wasn’t built to be alone. You can ignore me all you want, give me the silent treatment, whatever. I don’t need to talk to you. Just let me talk at you. He looks to her.
I need to know there’s someone else that can hear me.
Del files books with a pair of noise-cancelling headphone clamped over his ears. Grace trails. He pays her no mind.

(voice raised) I was making my way up the coast. My aunt got me this guide of the fifty U.S. landmarks you need to see before you die. One per state, and it ends at Niagara Falls. Have you been to Niagara Falls--? He walks right past her into the next aisle. Grace pulls a book from the nearest shelf and inserts it elsewhere, out of alphabetical order. She catches up to Del. Removes his headphones.
You like books?
Yeah, I do.
Me too!  27.
That’s great. He fastens the headphones over his ears once more.
We should start a book club!
Grace watches from the shore as Del sails. She polishes o beer, crushes the can and chucks it into the water. She raises one hand to eye level. Pinches the sailboat wi her index and middle fingers.
Del prepares an intricate sushi platter for himself, comp with wasabi, ginger and soy sauce. Grace observes the meal in awe.
Are you eating fish?
It’s salmon sashimi. He nips at the fish with a pair of chopsticks.
Some apocalypse this is. She gets up. Browses the stacks.
So why do you think it happened? Why did everyone die like that?
No use in speculating. I doubt we'll ever know for sure.
Maybe it was the Rapture.
Maybe. Probably not. He sucks his chopstick clean.  28.
Where were you when it--?
I was sleeping.
You were sleeping at two-thirty on a Tuesday afternoon?
I worked nights.
Where’d you work?
Here. I was the night custodian.
Huh.
It wasn’t so bad. My job was to keep everything in order. I like doing that. And they let me read whatever I wanted in my downtime. It was quiet. It was just me. Grace turns to him.
Didn't you ever feel lonely?
That’s the second time you've asked me that.
I’m curious.
You're curious? He pivots his chair to her.

You really want to know when I felt lonely? I felt lonely when there were 9,538 other people here, all of them looking at me like I was some kind of martian. Keeping their distance. Whispering to each other. That’s when I felt lonely. (MORE )
He stops. Del nods. She exits. Del folds 29.
Is that what you wanted to hear? Was that answer satisfactory, or would you like to ask me again? Settles.
I didn’t mean to raise my voice.
It’s okay. I can leave.
What?

I'll leave you alone. It’s fine. You've clearly got something good going here. Good for you, I mean. You’re happy, and I guess I thought I could-- I don’t know-- at the end of the day it’s not fair for me to put my shit on you. I’m sorry. Grace forces a smile.

What? Del cups a hand to his ear. Grace cranks down the window.
What is it?
You should put on your brights. It’s dark out there.
Oh. Yeah, thanks. She flicks on the brights.
See you around.
You don’t have to go just yet.
The last thing I need is for you to feel sorry for me. If I get going now I think I can make it to Niagara Falls by sun-up.
What’s in Niagara Falls?
It’s one of the landmarks in my aunt's guidebook. I was telling you earlier-- you must’ve had the headphones on. Anyways, it’s the last one and then that’s it.
That’s it?
It’s my last landmark.
What happens after that?
What do you mean?  31.
Once you've reached Niagara Falls. Where do you go afterwards? Up to Canada, or--? Grace shakes her head.
Stop.
Can you answer my question?
Why? What does it matter anyway? It’s not like you care.
You shouldn’t go to Niagara Falls. Not yet. You can stay here for a little while, get your bearings.
Stop. Just stop. Please.
What kinds of movies do you like?
Movies?

We have a great catalogue of DVDs back at the library. I watch them on laptops, the portable players, anything I can get my hands on. You could borrow one or two of them sometime. The DVDs, I mean. Drop them off in the return slot when you're finished. (a pause) Do you like comedies?
Yeah. Yeah, I like comedies.

We've got a whole section that’s just comedy films. And not just the mainstream stuff either. Some of the titles have been out of print for-- well, I guess they’re all out of print now, technically.  32.
Why are you saying all this? I thought you wanted to be alone.
I do. At the moment, your leaving here and never ever coming back is a very exciting prospect for me.
Thanks.

But if I’m forced to think about it long-term, I‘1l admit there’s a very slim possibility that there could come a day when I change my mind and decide that I could do with some company after all. But by that point you’d be long gone and it'd be virtually impossible for me to ever find you again.
Okay?
There’s a terrifying degree of permanency there, don’t you think?
I guess.
What I’m trying to say is, if you leave now our goose is cooked before it even hatches.
Cooked goose sounds pretty tasty right now.
I wouldn't know. I’m a pescatarian.
Of course you are. Del shrugs.
